author: drc74
title: TECH group is cancelled so many times
body: I feel disappointed that the TECH group is cancelled so many times. I feel that we would have benefitted because we could put forward about new suggestions. We as female patients hope this will change now a staff member is back from leave. We know that another staff member is really busy however putting us on hold is not making things better.

author: Freeb13
title: I was a bit concerned at lone worker status
body: I accessed the phlebotomy service at Plean Street through a controlled entry system & was met in the clinic area by the phlebotomist. The efficiency & professionalism of the staff member was faultless however I was a bit concerned at lone worker status of the phlebotomist. At a time when violence & aggression towards healthcare staff is at an all-time high, I'm concerned that management have left this worker exposed.

author: airqx57
title: Great experience
body: My experience was great. I was treated with the utmost gentle and relaxed time from I went in until I came out I cannot thank them enough for the service they provide for the elderly.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: browserrz68
title: Depression & drug abuse
body: It started happening when i was 13, this is when i started to feel depressed about everything including school, general mental health (self harm) and myself. I started stealing my mums pain medication and i was taking a couple to a few strips a day. fast forward to when I was 15, i was drinking alcohol and taking ecstasy and acid constantly and even did it on school grounds - and still taking the prescription painkillers. I overdosed a lot and was in and out of hospital every month or so, one time having all my front teeth smashed out from getting in trouble under the influence. I got sectioned not longer after and was under section 2 of the mental health act (28 days in hospital), mainly from being out of control on xanax and alcohol but all the problems combined into one big mess. 1 month passes and i head back home, finally clean. I fell in love for the first time in my life and was in a relationship for several months. It ended because i found out i was being cheated on, drug and alcohol use ramped up once again… suicidal tendencies deteriorated and i felt like a threat to myself and others, completely lost. Fast forward to age 17, regularly taking opiates/opioids, and drinking somewhat heavily and definitely frequently and still taking acid. A year of that hell goes by and i tried to take my own life again over being rejected by a girl, now aged 18 and now diagnosed with bpd. Still drinking and taking dihydrocodeine, my best friend and my ex who cheated on me as stated here passed away, both accidental. Heartbroken and lost in life i kept drowning myself away in grief, met another girl almost a year later, together for a year and a few months and broke up due to complications (heavy on the dihydrocodeine at this point). After being severely betrayed and overall upset about life again, i decided it was time to get some help, now aged 20 - i opened up to my dad, mum and stepdad about what’s been going on and what my substance misuse was doing to me and how it’s affected my life from the start of using, very emotional time for all of us. being difficult to open up about it, a good friend of mine referred me to try Inclusion and I’ve felt a lot more stability and have been put on a treatment plan for my opiate addiction, with it being both maturity and support from inclusion i’ve felt a lot better with how i am with things (how to cope, having people to talk to who have share’d similar experiences) and i strongly recommend it if you need desperate help, the service response was better than most and the staff are understanding and experienced with mental health and substance misuse as a whole, great service for the ones out there who feel trapped in that pit of despair. I’m not completely cured but inclusion builds up routine and general help on all vectors

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Bubbly12
title: Overall my stay was OK
body:
I was admitted to MAU after a long wait in A&E the stay itself was okay, but a lot could have been better. The patients in the ward were lovely and friendly and to be honest made my stay bearable and less frightening.  
Most of the staff were nice and helpful but some could have been a little better especially when there is no visiting so I was even more vulnerable and scared than normal,I know they are extremely busy and rushed of their feet and do a good job, but I think they should also remember to show some kindness and empathy towards their patients as I think sometimes they tend to forget. Over all my stay was okay but I was glad to get home.  
I would like to give a big thank you to one nurse who was looking after me who was absolutely fantastic and so kind and caring. Nothing was any bother, really went out their way to help me and I can’t thank them enough. Also there was another nurse who was brilliant as well, couldn’t do enough for me went out his way to help no matter how busy he was and his manners were impeccable such a lovely kind person . I would also like to thank the bank nurse who was very kind, found me sitting on the chair crying, helped me and listened to me. That small bit of kindness made such a difference.  
A thank you to everyone who helped.Some of the other patients expressed that they weren’t happy either with some things either, so I was not the only one. It’s a great shame as it is a nice ward.

author: Neil28
title: Aberdeen Royal Infirmary & Community Nurses
body:
As a disabled male, paralysed from the waist since birth. NHS Grampian appear to be refusing my request to retrain my bowels bowel regime or re-introduce system for this purpose which previously allowed me to lead something approximating a normal. Their only suggestion are either, to re-introduce system, which over an extended period (a matter of months) or to allow me to soil myself and then get me cleaned-up. In my opinion this demonstrated a total lack of any duty of care, or any attempt to preserve my dignity  
Where are the disabled supposed to go for help?  
when NHS Grampian has absolutely no facilities to help the severely disabled that I can use, especially those within my age group.  
I suffered a shoulder injury at the beginning of the pandemic, which lead to my being hospitalised at this point my existence was stopped I was then transferred to a care where a possible alternative regime was instigated.  
However, this regime soon proved completely unsuccessful and further eroded what was left of my dignity and self-confidence.  
I then contracted covid-19 and, was as a result transferred to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, During the whole of my admission to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, no attempt whatsoever was made to manage my bowels.  
On my discharge from Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, I was moved to a care home and an attempt was made to re-instate my existing regime, however, I was soon told that the information which had been given by ARI was incomplete and staff at the care home even specified that, had they known the exact details of my bowel regime, I would not have been admitted here. I have fed this back to various medical professionals (and others), however no real action has been taken.  
I am supposed to be moving to a sheltered Housing facility on a permanent basis, as, (depending on who I talk to) I am told that  
1. A system needs to be in place and  
working well  
Or-  
2. Bowel training can be undertaken at my  
new flat (however, this is with the  
proviso that, if the training doesn’t go  
well it may be deemed that either I’m  
unsuitable for this complex or it isn’t  
suitable for my needs.  
The end result being that I’m the tenant of  
a flat which I can’t live in within a Shelter Housing which was specifically picked as it appeared to suit my needs.  
The impact on my future life and my mental  
well-being is nothing sort of incalculable.  
NHS Grampian have completely, utterly and totally ignored this situation (at least the bowel aspect, which has been ongoing for well over 18 months  
I’m now in the farcical position of being now well into decorating and furnishing a flat which it looks increasingly like I may not be able to occupy.  
I’m left with the strong sensation, and belief that of you are (like me), a patient whose issues are “not exactly the norm”.  
You have real problems. I also feel that As a disabled male, paralysed from the waist since birth and having had a catastrophic stroke, it’s fair to say that I have been hugely let down by NHS Grampian as a whole.  
They have thus far refused my request to retrain my bowels by reintroducing a system which is proven to allow me to lead a normal life.  
There has (in my opinion) been a massive and shocking lack of a duty of care or anything even resembling a duty of care.  
Decisions made now will have an incalculably impact on my future life and my mental well being, Potentially for the rest of my life, whether or not others within NHS Grampian, is open to debate.  
NHS Grampian are totally ignoring the plight of myself as a disabled person in this city.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: ElaineLD
title: Excellent Care
body:
My Mum has been in Stonehouse hospital for the past two and a half weeks for rehabilitation after major surgery, and will be in for another four weeks at least.  
All nursing staff are exceptional, and take time to provide the best care possible and I can honestly say, when I leave Mum after visiting I know she is in safe hands.  
Regardless of how short staffed they are during these difficult times, both day and night shift still smile and carry on with their jobs with a very high standard.  
Also a mention for the physio team who provide a fantastic service and are working hard with Mum to get her stronger.  
So thank you to all staff at Stonehouse Hospital for providing the highest care to patients, it is very much appreciated.

author: cygnusdx39
title: Top class care in the community
body:
The Care nurses have been coming round on a daily basis for a six week period. When they were last here, they left this card asking me for my experiences.  
I was referred to the local podiatrist because I have a right leg with no ankle in it, and my left leg is shorter then the right. I'd been attending for an orthesis as the foot doesn't bend. There the local podiatrist discovered I had an infection on the tip of the toe next to the big toe on my left foot. This seemed very very curious, as there was nothing I could see on the tip, but when the professionals say there is something there, you say ok and you listen to them. They recommended I go on antibiotics, by IV injection for six weeks, seven days a week.  
So, I took their advice, and thats the route we took. Every day for six weeks, thats 42 visits, we've had someone come here into my home and made up the antibiotics. They left us with the ingredients and mixed it up as needed each time, and made sure the line had been put in properly and had been cleared, by passing saline solution in presumably. They would then connect it up, and started to put in the antibiotics in, it went in over a five minute period. It wasn't a case of just pushing the injection in, it went in over a period of about three to five minutes, normally around 4.  
I had 42 of these injections, and we were well pleased with the way it was done. From the first week, the staff were all very friendly, all very helpful, all very keen to monitor my blood samples on a weekly basis - every Monday they would take a sample and test it, it would come back on the Tuesday and they'd tell you yes, your blood levels are coming down. They started at, lets say, '20', then they'd tell you that it had gone down to say, '18', so moving in the right direction. This went on on a weekly basis.  
They also changed the line once, they had found it was leaking a very very little amount, and secondly put it in the other arm which made it even better because this gave me freedom to do exercises with my left arm.  
So this is where we are, 42 visits are over, giving feedback about the Belfast area County Down nurses. There is a similar service in Antrim, over the lough, but they only offer this in tablet form rather than by injection.  
I kept a record of all the nurses who came and went. The vast majority of the nurses, 99% had all been in local hospitals and they had worked on wards for a number of years. They were all experienced nurses, and they brought that experience to the fore. They did say that they preferred this way, it allowed them to meet different types of people they could talk to, and they weren't being hurried along to answer the ringing of the bells, and people shouting. They much preferred it like this.  
On a couple of occasions, the nurse brought along an assistant. The assistant would do the job under the nurse's guidance. One is currently at Queens hospital Belfast with only a number of months to go, another was doing a degree through Open University, in their final year. Yet again, they were very helpful, very nice, very attentive. This is true for all of the staff I saw, nurses and assistants, they were all as good as each other.  
I don't think any thing can be done better, though I have nothing much to compare it to. What I did receive was par excellent, I couldn't wish for better.  
I thought the way they went about their work though, they were overrun by paperwork, it took up a good bit of their time. Say they were in for 30 minutes, probably more, say 45 minutes. Of that 45 minutes, at least 10 to 15 minutes were 1) preparing the injection, and 2) filling in all the details, who they were, my details, my blood pressure, pulse rate, all those things. All documenting what they were doing. They left me with one of those yellow sharps buckets for needles, so they wouldn't need to carry them away on a daily basis. All the stuff was put in there, and all the clothes they had were taken off, rolled up and put in a bag, and put straight into the normal bin. The hygiene of these people was particularly good, the first thing they would do when they came in was wash and dry their hands, it was all very good.  
They were all top class.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mumc
title: 111 and Edinburgh Sick Kids Minor Injuries
body:
Called 111 this morning about my child's ankle as they couldn’t weight bear after a fall. It took about 15 minutes for my call to be answered but when it was staff were polite, friendly, professional and helpful.  
Our trip to Sick Kids Minor Injuries went very smoothly and all the staff we met - car park attendant, receptionist, nurses, students, radiographer and the consultant were all excellent and very friendly. So thankful for our amazing NHS staff who do a brilliant job. 👏👏👏

author: parent1234
title: Better communication needed
body: I have been reading stories about how amazing everyone is here, and this is mostly true. However, I feel some of the children are not getting all their treatment done properly or in good time. Need better communication between nurses and doctors. And there was the other factor on two occasions of their being a hair in the bowl of fruit served. You would of thought hygiene would be better especially when it comes to food for a children's ward!

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Anya76
title: Incredible work
body:
I would like to say big thank you to Dr Athanasidiasis , urology team in ward 209 ( doctors, nurses and support workers, student doctor and dr Anna from night shift) and invasive radiology team (doctors, nurses, support workers, student nurse from Shetland and support worker from France who is going to be a midwife) for incredible work you have done. I was admitted for a procedure on my kidney. To preserve my kidney a team has been working hard for 3 hrs wearing heavy x-ray protective aprons.  
I was surrounded by angels during my hospitalisation. You were very professional, gentle, supportive and absolutely amazing.Thank you from top of my heart.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership
Office of Rhoda Grant, MSP for Highlands and Islands

author: ElaineMc
title: Caring Thyroid Cancer support
body:
During both my surgeries in Daisy Hill Hospital April 2020 and Craigavon Area Hospital June 2020 for my Thyroidectomy, I was treated with the utmost care and kindness during Covid times and throughout all my follow ups by ENT & the nursing care teams. They treated me with great compassion and always listened to my concerns.  
Due to Cancer surgery complications, I was diagnosed with Vocal chord paralysis resulting in total loss of vocal, acute shortness of breath and swallow issues which were extremely challenging. With extensive speech therapy for 6 months and truly amazing care, support and kindness shown to me from Jacqueline, Speech, language & Swallow therapist, who started my initial session by saying ' slow and steady wins the race' we worked so hard on my communication skills and in getting my vocal back to a level that I could chat again ... hugely important for me being someone who loves to talk and enjoy the craic!! However with continuous shortness of breath, limited depth or strength to my vocal ability, unable to do anything on exertion, and my overall quality of life - on discussion with my ENT consultant surgeon Mr McCaul, Catherine and Kate - Trachi nurse specialists we decided that the only fix to enhance my overall quality of life, to provide more air into my lungs and enhance my breathing and vocal ability was to have a Tracheostomy.A life changing and life adapting surgery which I had in October and which I am now recuperating from.All the nursing team in 1 West Elective Ward in Craigavon Area Hospital became my family for 10 days and showered me with so much care, support, help and kindness throughout my stay. It was definitely the little things that I will always remember .. from Valerie and Danielle washing my hair, to the hand holding and offering tissues on the more difficult days, to helping me, Gillian making me a cuppa, reading my hand writing on the chalk board and to Bronagh, Leah, Gina and Glaiza willing me on and telling me how well I was doing , showing me how to care for 'Talleluh' my Trachi and how all the team helped me so much. Catherine and Kate, Trachi nurse specialists always make me feel at ease and with their friendship, dedicated and ongoing care, attention & training pre and post surgery with my family and I, we feel much more confident to face this next chapter in my healing journey. With 3 surgeries during the Covid Pandemic thank you for all your caring support.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

author: Hopalong Leith
title: Persistent loss of hearing aids/teeth in hospital
body:
I am livid! My elderly father is back in Forth Valley Hospital for the 4th time this year. On every occasion, they've lost his teeth, or hearing aids or both. The score for this year is 1 bottom set of teeth missing, 1 top set of teeth missing (recovered after 2 weeks) and 4, possibly 6 hearing aids in total gone AWOL. Every time he goes in, they disappear without trace and the staff are totally unconcerned about it. It's of no more consequence to them than the loss of a biscuit - probably less so.  
They make no attempt to track them down until you kick up a considerable fuss and even then rarely succeed. There seems to be no concept in the minds of the nursing staff that an elderly man with dementia needs to be able to hear and to eat!!!! I actually had a nurse tell me this evening that my father wasn't eating well. She seemed rather surprised when I pointed out that this was because half his teeth were missing. Do I have to spell it out for them???  
The irony is that the hearing aids are national health ones, so their carelessness is costing their own employer a fortune - no wonder they can't afford more staff! What do I have to do to get them into the mindset that this is personal property and vital to the patient's welfare? The stress on relatives (in this case me) is HUGE without having to compensate for their lack of interest.

author: JMM48
title: Wonderful efficient service
body:
I was reluctant to attend A+E with my wrist injury as I know how busy and under pressure everyone is at the moment. However I finally took advice of family and attended the Minor Injuries Unit at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital. After being screened very efficiently at the A&E Door by one of the senior nurses, I was directed over to Minor Injuries.  
I was warmly welcomed and booked in there by a very polite and kind receptionist. I was then called in by Andrew, the Emergency Nurse Practitioner, who provided excellent prompt care and following an X-Ray, was able to tell me I had indeed broken my wrist and arranged for me to be called by Orthopaedics the following day. Charlie, the healthcare assistant fitted me with a splint to wear until I heard from them. I was in and out of the hospital in under an hour - wonderful, efficient service!  
Yesterday morning, as promised by Andrew, I received the phone call from Orthopaedics to attend the Plaster Room that afternoon where I was reviewed, plaster applied and follow up appointment arranged again all in under an hour.  
I cannot praise the staff highly enough for the level of care and attention I received during my visits.

author: waltzmw88
title: Removing a small wedge from my right ear
body:
The surgeon Mr Alcock and his team were very caring. The process was carefully explained in advance and my questions answered. The local anaesthetic was carefully progressively injected… no pain at all. The chunk of ear was painlessly cut out and then 10 stitches put in. The nurses carefully plastered up the wound so that I looked like Mr. Spock!  
Altogether the experience couldn’t have been better.  
I was told to remove the dressing after 48 hours. This was done by my daughter (less squeamish than my wife) ….. looks a bit bloody, but we’ll leave it alone for a bit before we wash the ear.

author: emdub
title: Caring camhs service
body:
I have been seeing Kim and Marissa for a while because I felt very anxious and ended up really struggling with everything. School was hard and I didn't want to do lots of things because I worried so much about feeling sick. They are both really nice and helped me so much when I was struggling and I know they helped me be more confident and achieve some of my goals.  
I think anyone who gets to work with them is lucky because they care about people getting better and are so encouraging. I am now finished working with them and feel so much better than I did at the start. They listened to me all the time and that was when I found it hard to listen to them when I felt anxiety was taking over me. They didn't give up on helping me.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

links.id: Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services

author: Radolynsky
title: Sorted straight away
body: Lorraine, Janine and David, you took me by surprise today. I came for an appointment at minor operations in Larbert hospital thinking I would have an examination of my ailment and bang... I had an operation instead, fairly minor indeed, but the problem hopefully sorted straight away. Thank you for your help guys. And David, I wish you to go to the gig so good you have never been to in you life yet.

title: Great service received from reception staff
body: This particular reception staff was very considerate to my little boys needs. Although I couldn’t get an appointment that day for my 3 year old boy the staff member listened to my situation and offered assistance. I was really pleased that the doctor was able to help after receiving request from staff. Had this member not took the time to listen and be considerate I don’t think my experience would of been the same. Thank you so much

author: watermn45
title: Service difficult to access
body:
It took over a week of trying to get through on the phones. Sometimes it doesn't go through at all, sometimes you get put on hold for an hour and then it automatically hangs up, sometimes busy tone.  
When I finally got through on their phone-line it cut out halfway. I thought they would make an effort to call back but never did. They told me a doctor would call me that day but they never did.

title: Good Service
body: I rang the surgery and subsequently was referred to a doctor that morning given the nature of my condition. It did take some time to get through (approx 25 mins) but my experience is that an early morning call mid week is more likely to secure a quicker response. I was seen that morning and given alternative medication along with a referral to the hospital. The alternative medication worked well and I await an appointment which I am optimistic will reveal the source of the problem. Generally speaking I feel the staff at the Practice do their best to provide an excellent service in very difficult circumstances. One has to be patient and understanding of this and make use "speaker 'phone" if the queue is long at busy times. Try and 'phone mid week if possible.

readBy.name: Meadowgreen Health Centre & The Avenue Medical Practice

author: DRC71
title: Seclusion Women's service, handled well
body:
I was secluded last week.  The staff dealt with this very well especially ATL Jonno.
He listened to me when I told him I didn’t feel safe, I walked to seclusion, and was allowed to take my mp3 player, reading book, puzzle book and crayons and my own bedding.
Later that night my mp3 charger was brought to me.
I felt this went very well and I feel that staff involved deserve praise.

author: stoneng68
title: My father suffering from advanced Alzheimer's disease
body:
I fully appreciate the work your service provides for those who otherwise would have no voice. However...  
Whilst I fully appreciate your support in giving those who would otherwise not have a voice, a way for their opinions to be heard, I feel that there is currently a complete lack of understanding on the part of some of your independent advocates when it comes to dealing with clients who have advanced Alzheimer's disease.  
My father is in a care home because I was no longer able to meet his needs at home. It was an extremely difficult decision for me to make but I am pleased with the care he receives and he is gradually settling.  
However, since he has been contacted by your advocate he has become unsettled again. I have spoken to the care home and the advocate about this. Every time my dad has been visited by one of your advocates he is upset and becomes angry with myself and the care staff. Today I have had an awful visit with him as due to what the advocate said to him on a previous visit, my father is convinced he is going to live somewhere else. The only person who has mentioned this is your advocate. Not only is this not possible but both myself and your advocate are happy with the care he receives and my dad WAS quite settled.  
I have spoken to your advocate asking what they said to my dad. Apparently they asked him a hypothetical question about where he would like to live. Who, in their right mind, would ask a person with advanced Alzheimer's a hypothetical question! My dad has no capacity to understand. I'm afraid to say that your advocate's presence is causing trouble for me and is upsetting and unsettling my dad. A person who lacks mental capacity easily becomes worried and unsettled and I feel your staff need training to recognise that. This has really unsettled my dad and made him angry with me. I have to say I am really upset. It's hard enough having to make the decision to let your parent go into a care home without this.  
As I said previously I appreciate that your service speaks up for and protects the vulnerable but please ensure they have the necessary training in how to do this in a productive manner.  
My dad is as happy as he can be in the circumstances. I only wish thinks could be different for him but they can't. Don't make this any harder for him or me please.

author: januarydm37
title: Figuring out the issue
body: Reoccurring yeast infection symptoms causing stress and anxiety, doctors and nurses were amazing, figuring out the issue and offering solutions to help. Amazing service put me at ease really grateful for the help and support I was given.

author: legout62
title: Everything was methodical and quick
body: I was welcomed politely, asked to sanitise and took my seat. In a few minutes, was called out, proceeded and handed over my small container, shown the door. Everything was methodical and quick. I was out of the building after a satisfactory service. Thank you "staff". Job well done 👍🏾

author: librahs54
title: Testing with partner
body: Excellent care and service, Kim was considerate and supportive.

author: Stuarty56
title: Thank you for saving my life.
body:
In August 2021 I woke up in morning feeling ok. I went upstairs to get pair of shorts as it was nice day. No problems walking upstairs or any different feelings.  
My wife was going out in car to do usual stuff and said to me ‘there is a sandwich for you later and what are you going to do while I am away.  
Don’t worry about me as I have some things to watch on television.  
Next thing I knew I was waking up in ICU about 4 or 5 days later.  
I had no idea what had happened but saw my wife at bedside. She had told me I had a heart attack which I could not fathom how. I knew I was struggling coz of tubes etc etc in my body..  
Seemingly I had called ambulance myself, called my wife then opened front door to allow Paramedics access to me. I think I collapsed after that.  
The Paramedics (Leven ambulance crew) saved my life initially as they worked on me for about 15 mins to bring me back.  
In ICU I was very agitated and restless. But the staff were just brilliant with me and looked after me so well.  
They helped wash me and did all that I needed to make me comfortable. I was then due to go to Royal but unfortunately no bed for me. On the Friday my wife came to visit me and I said I am going to the Royal today at some point.  
Unbeknown to me my wife did not like colour of me but obviously said nothing to me. I told my wife to go home because hopefully be away to royal. I went to toilet and came out and had this horrible pain in my chest/abdomen area. I shouted on nurse that I was struggling badly and immediately they hooked me up to machine and sprayed under my tongue.  
The head Doctor said this man needs to go to Edinburgh now.  
An ambulance was despatched and as quick as they could got me over to royal.  
Through the night I had a few more setbacks (heart attacks) and I was becoming quite scared. The nurses etc were brilliant with me reassuring me all was going to be ok. In the morning I was taken to the theatre and doctor  
Fitted a stent as I had one artery blocked. I can’t remember how long it took but I was back in recovery ward to have my breakfast. How FANTASTIC was that. My wife and son came in to see me and told me I was back to normal colour again.  
The weekend went quite quickly and was discharged on the Monday around dinner time.  
Once home the only problem I had was my rib cage and underneath were incredibly sore but I knew reason for that. I started going for small walks as quickly as I felt able to as I knew I needed strength back to better cope with what had happened. I am now on tablets to help cope with repair to heart etc. The follow up from NHS has been so good. Because of NHS I am alive today and that is a fact that cannot be argued with.  
3 months on I am back working (Small part time job) and comfortably walking good distances and not out of breath.  
I have no memory of initial setback so I have no bad dreams or thoughts at all.  
Once again I want to say to everyone involved in saving my life and looking after me so well in ambulance,hospital and after care a massive  
THANK YOU.

author: Bobby12Bobby
title: Screening
body: Good service. Friendly staff. Confidential.

author: wezenef46
title: Getting myself back into society
body:
Anne was very good at finding different resources online for help and groups. She helped me with setting and reaching goals, writing down my feelings to share with my husband and encouraging me to focus better.
Anne was very east to talk and listen to and put me at ease.

author: jezz101
title: Refusal of emergency outpatient and emergency care
body:
I am a very ill man, who has been refused treatment by the NHS for years, I have multiple health problems, most of which affected me after a negligent surgeon injected me with a steroid that had been advised would cause a terrible interaction with my HIV medication, this gave me a sustained steroid overdose that lasted for 14 days, otherwise known as Iatrogenic Cushions Syndrome.  
The NHS, instead of treating me for the collapse in my health that they caused, as been refusing me any outpatient care at all, this involves the whole of the NHS (multiple trusts).  
In late August this year, I was extremely unwell with the symptoms of Adrenal Crisis, which I had been warned about when I was hospitalised after my overdose years before (2015).  
Then I was very sick and was bedridden for 4-5 days. I also lost half a stone in weight. Once I had recovered enough, I called 111 for advice, as I had been refused care at Worthing Hospital. 111 put me through to a doctor that knee about Adrenal problems, she said I needed emergency care and called an ambulance for me. When I arrived at A & E I was waiting for help for 3 hours. When a doctor saw me she said that A & E do not deal with Adrenal problems, and they could do nothing more for me.  
I was distraught, and had to hobble home with my walking stick, in tears, after being unable to eat for days and being very unwell.  
The public need to be warned that if you are ill because of a NHS mistake, you could have all care denied. The Adrenal Crises that I suffer can cause coma or death. I am being abandoned to the point of possible death by the NHS, who actually caused my health problems – Multi Joint Hypertrophic arthritis, pre-diabetes, Bilateral Necrosis of hips, an Auto Immune disease and Periosteal Uptake (something related to bone lesions).  
The public should be warned that if they are damaged by an NHS mistake, they could be refused all care.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Tessa77
title: Confusion over an appointment
body: I received an appointment letter to attend the hospital, then late yesterday I received a text telling me it would be a phone review. This was confusing as I hadn’t attended an appointment before & there were practical things eg walking on a treadmill that couldn’t be done over the phone. I phoned the booking office and the member answering the phone was unable to clarify which information was correct. She tried to contact a nurse etc… but wasn’t able to reach anyone and suggested I phone back tomorrow. I came out of a meeting to a voice message explaining which information was correct. Taking time out of, what I’m sure is a busy job to ensure I had the right information without having to phone again. Small things matter too. Thank you

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Cin87
title: Nice clinic atmosphere
body:
Kim was fab. Both on phone and during treatment.
I didnt feel awkward or stupid 

Very nice clinic atmosphere

author: Goggsy50
title: I cannot praise them any higher
body:
I had a problem when left arm and hand froze and locked up with no power. Phoned 111 and told to get to Larbert hospital A+E where I waited to be seen. Eventually seen and transferred to Clinical Assessment Unit. After a wait I was seen by the Stroke Team, Doctors Leitch and Copeland who were excellent in their attention and explanations of what I had, what will happen and treatment.  
I cannot praise them any higher for attention and also all the Team in that department for the attention everyone gave, even the Tea lady. Even in these times of very busy everyone stayed calm,coped with pressure and carried on ,how has got to be seen. A very big thanks to all you may have saved me from further issues by your help. Thank you all!  
Anyone attending hospital, please be patient, respect others and you will be rewarded.

author: Helen20210
title: Mental Health and working
body:
I have struggled with mental health due to trauma in my past growing up and what I went through.  
I was abused as a child and then in my teens and young adult in very abusive relationships that left me traumatized and loss of self worth.  
Work was always my escape and I have always been good at my job and I have a passion to help others because of my own traumas.3 years ago through over working and not looking after my mental health I had a break down and I struggled with my work, which I did not get help when I should have and just carried on, although my company could see I was unwell I could not see how I was deteriorating, in my work I lost all control of my emotions and felt with out work I had nothing as all I had done for 23 years was work and work hard long hours and days because I felt I had to do this to stop everything else in my life from going under.3 years ago when I had my break down I was ready to end everything due to not being supported at work and not looking after myself and my work was very stressful. I made the decision to move back to my home town and be closer to family, but with what had happened to me and the break down I struggled with my confidence in doing the job I have done for years and done well. So I went from one job to another not lasting more then 5 to 6 months before feeling too stressed and leaving, which did not help in my mental health and did not look good on my CV.I started to get support for my mental health which was the first time in 20 years and had to admit that I needed help. I was then assigned support and help, but covid hit. I would still go through jobs and not settle. until this summer I decided to go self employed and try and balance my life better I was given support from inclusion that helped me to understand that I can go self employed and still be supported and have a safety net just in case with universal credits whilst I develop my own career. Learning how to not put everything in one thing and learn to slow down and take care of my mental health as well as have a back up of support for when I had moments of worry and the whole what if, I had someone I can talk to my worries and what I may need help in and how to deal with my emotions in a positive way. Inclusion helped me in not to get a job as I could do that but in keeping myself in balance and continuity as this is what I needed and still a long way to go and I learnt is not a sprint I get there in time.Am I fully there.. no but in this time period I learnt that I don't have to work crazy hours and have all responsibility to be happy and content in what I am doing. but also I can be self employed and I can do this if I just have good balance.I am in therapy as well and I have to realise that I need to take time out and I have to be more mindful of when I need to rest and my mental health needs to be healthy and with out this then everything else will not work. but I need to be happy in my work, I now teach in which I have a passion for to help others in understanding in my limitations .No matter how old you are I believe we all need someone to listen to and not judge to hear our issues and not fix them but to know there is someone there that is there to listen. We don't all have the answers and we never have them but to have a support network and being able to say yeah I have Mental health but that does not defy who I am and what I can become Normal is an Illusion what is normal for a spider is Chaos for the fly

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Barracuda
title: The attitude was not necessary
body:
Previously I have attended a sexual health clinic with no issues, it was in at another clinic and the person who spoke to me was lovely, I couldn't speak highly enough about her. I thought it would be the same experience in Coatbridge. Now firstly, the "hello my name is..." campaign wasn't emphasised in NHS Lanarkshire for nothing, the person I saw that night had no inclination to introduce themself and it felt like our consultation turned into an interrogation and was overall uncomfortable.  
I get that there are medical reasons as to why other types of birth control can't be used if you're overweight or have been sexually active but there is a way to talk to someone, the eye rolls, sarcasm, overall couldn't be bothere. The attitude was not necessary.  
Now I'm in my late 20's. Imagine if I was a young girl being introduced to these things received a consultation like that? My heart would break for them. It's their body and they should never feel like they've done something wrong by choosing to use birth control or by explaining how their body has reacted to types of bc. Also, when they ask questions like if you've been involved in domestic violence or experienced an eating disorder, how could you confide in someone like this? Two questions that could potentially save someone's life if the staff member actually seemed to care when they asked.  
Credit where credit is due, they did apologise for a conversation that a doctor had with me over the phone as they didn't read all the factors before telling me my options, which turns out neither of them were suitable. And they did find me a suitable time and place to see a doctor in 12 weeks time.  
I know nurses and healthcare staff can be burnt out with the pandemic and I appreciate all that they've went through, all I am trying to say is don't treat anyone like they are wasting your time, I am not a burden and I only seek help when I need it. Maybe reintroduce "Hello my name is..." to remind staff the importance.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: virgogd74

Thank you also to Dr Simpson, Morag and Anne who supported me during my MVA. The whole experience was very challenging for me personally but made so much easier by an absolutely outstanding team and cannot praise them all highly enough.

author: Peajay
title: Making a scary experience almost fun
body: Today I had a procedure at the Dermatology department Treliske, Truro. I had perfect surgery and perfect nursing and I am extremely grateful to Dr Hood, Sonia and Hilary for making a scary experience almost fun! I talked non stop and they managed to work extremely carefully and kindly in spite of my relentless stories! The team were professional, calm and experienced and I feel very lucky to have had this amazing care today. Thank you all.

author: earthjf63
title: ADHD during remote Masters Studies
body:
Although the symptoms and characteristics were always present with myself over the years, the remote aspect of studying really highlighted them and the difficulties they present.  
I was facing difficulties with my organisation, time management and concentration in general. This has always been a common thing for me, however due to the remote nature of my studies they felt more profound. I found myself being more restless and having more lapse in concentration than ever before. This in turn was affecting my workload and deadline schedules, online exams limited to only a couple of hours became a huge burden for me.  
I contacted my university support team who referred me to their "Do It Profiler" assessment and then from those results I was referred to my local GP. After an appointment with my GP I was referred to the NeSS team.  
After submitting the required forms and details from myself and immediate family members I was told to wait for the review. A while later my review was completed and I had my first meeting with Dr Gillott.  
The consultation with Dr Gillott helped me understand my situation better. Her high level of understanding and knowledge helped me open up about my issues and symptoms.  
Although the waiting times are long, understandably due to the current climate and it being a relatively new service with high referrals.I'm happy that I'm now one step closer to getting the help and necessary treatment. I'm excited to see what happens next and how my daily life will change as well as my academics. Would definitely recommend the service but just know there is a waiting list and may take a while.

body: Needed dental surgery at North Devon / Oral & Maxillofacial Dept and cannot thank enough the whole team for such a professional and caring experience. Very nervous going in but reassured at each step and so big thank you to Alex, Jenny, Julie and Sammy. Well done again NHS!

author: Sally Anne
title: Good bedside manner
body: Dr had a very good bedside manner, I felt very comfortable and the nurse was very friendly too.

author: 72Max
title: High standard of care
body:
Thank you so much, I could not have received a higher standard of care, professionalism, compassion than I experienced here during my day surgery. The way the staff help you fully understand what you are there for and in checking all procedures, constantly asking if require anything at all to make you more comfortable during your stay.  
I was advised by letter to be in at 08:00 although my surgery did not happen until 13:30 but in this I had no issues as to see how the staff go about their duties and listen to what they talk about and also how they talk to patients is very clear and warm. I received many apologies over the time I had to wait and although this could make you apprehensive and more anxious I felt relaxed in the environment.  
I now understand that yourselves have to be so focused on each patient but collectively know about everything. From walking into the Unit to walking out of the Unit I felt treated like a VIP and between Ali, Steven, Mr Walmsley, Andreas, Marie, Carrie, Ruth, Helen and even the important staff who prepped the beds for the next patient. Apologies to who I have missed but you are an absolute credit to the NHS. Thankyou again and on a positive note thankyou for the experience and care - I hope not to see you's again for a long long time :-)

author: Janh
title: Thank you to the consultants
body:
This is to say, THANK YOU, to the —Consultants of ‘The Orthopaedic Department’ —and the staff of -Ward 9a.  
My sister, has been treated by the above, for approximately, four (4 ) weeks now, since badly falling in the Care Home she was in. She broke her hip and fractured her skull. This among many other health problems. One of the most difficult being—‘Rapid Onset Dementia ‘. She is naturally, very difficult to manage but the ‘Orthopaedic Consultants’ and Ward 9a, have coped amazingly  
Thank you all, from all the family.  
If her Social Workers had been as excellent, instead of ignoring her family and causing immense worry. It would have been perfect, during this dreadful time.

author: Hai
title: So grateful for everyone's time and patience
body:
I was recently admitted to 11B for an infected cyst on my neck. I was seen at the treatment room first by Kirstie. She was very friendly and approachable, I was very reassured. When I was seen by Miss Clark she advised that I would need to be admitted for IV Antibiotics and E+D of the infection. Miss Clark was exactly the kind of surgeon I needed, quick decision making with good follow up and a good sense of humour!  
The surgery was the following day and it went very smoothly.  
My wound has now healed, I was given a pack of wound management resources by Kirstie so I could keep my wound clean and dressed. This definitely helped to speed up the healing process and leave a nice, clean scar.  
Every single nurse, HCA, porter, radiographer, and doctor that I came into contact with were amazing. The ward were clearly under pressure at times due to staffing but this did not hinder their caring nature. As a nurse myself, I felt very cared for (a little too much sometimes, I don't need you to change my bed for me! But us nurses are known to be the worst patients anyway haha).  
I want to give a special shout out to all the nurses in 11B, Kirstie, Miss Clark and her Reg, all the theatre staff, and the radiographers who performed my CT.  
It gives you amazing perspective when you're on the other side of care and I'm so grateful for everyone's time and patience.

author: Ciagr99
title: Fabulous progress on stroke ward
body:
My Mother transferred to Ward A1, AAH from RVH in October having suffered a stroke. The progress she has made whilst in A1 has been fabulous and as a family we are so thankful and grateful for all of the excellent care and treatment she has received from the Ward Team. In my mother’s own words “they would do anything for me, and are so good to me”. To know that she is in safe hands is so comforting especially when visiting is restricted in Covid times.  
We are so grateful to the team with special thanks to Liz, Sophie, Carmella, Arietta and Minnie for taking time to update us and reassure us even though they are run off their feet. Briege (stroke nurse) was exceptional also. We honestly appreciate the time you took with us as a family which was so so helpful . We would also like to thank Dr Andrew for taking time to talk to us and update us on her progress.  
The Mental Health Liaison Service (MHLS) based in AAH have been exceptional throughout my Mother’s stay in A1. At a time where my Mother has experienced great fear and anxiety about her current situation and the future, the MHLS team has brought a great source of comfort to her and us as a family. Nothing was too much bother for this team. From ensuring my Mother had the treatment needed to help her along her journey, to providing daily reviews on the Ward and talking to us as a family , we will be forever grateful. Special thanks to Dr Anthony, Ruth, Christina and Anne for all of your care, treatment and support.  
Thank you to the whole multidisciplinary team - forever grateful.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: New Moray Mum
title: Disappointed with Health Visiting service
body:
Since my daughter was born in 2020 the care from the health visiting team has been disappointing.  
We got seen at 10 days and 6 weeks but after that it has just been phonecalls. Initially we were allowed to use the scales to check her weight but after some time this stopped due to covid. However covid had been ongoing before we were even under the care of the health visitors.  
She got her 8 month check at 9 months old.  
We then got her 13-15 month check at 13 months but we had to go to the health visitor department rather than them coming to our home.  
Recently I have tried to phone the health visiting team to discuss something I am worried about with my daughter to get a voice message that says due to sickness and annual leave no one will be in the office until Tuesday of next week (I phoned Monday the week prior). It continued to say to leave a message and someone will get back to you on their return. I am extremely frustrated you can't speak to anyone for over a week. There is no alternative number given. And I imagine they will have a lot of messages on their return so won't necessarily get back to mums on that day.  
I find the lack of health visiting support very disappointing and feel there needs to be a major improvement in the service. Covid has stopped a lot of services but there is still new mums/worried mums/mums with a question who can't speak to anyone or see anyone. Reassurance from a health visitor would be so beneficial but it's just not there. How can they build up a rapport with families over the phone..

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: arazr53
title: Took time to explain what was happening
body:
Elderly parent admitted to ward due to testing positive for Covid, low O2 levels and infection.  
Although I was not allowed to visit i did get to wave through the double doors when bringing in clothing which meant a great deal to physically see them.  
The nurses in charge of their care took time to explain what was happening to my parent, how they were responsing and their results of their blood work that day. The nurses took time to respond to all my questions (and there were a lot). I never once felt like they were rushing me off the phone and always came away feeling re-assured and calmer about the whole situation.  
When you can't see a relative daily or chat to them due to them being so ill or unable to work a phone you are totally reliant on the medical staff. Not only did they care for my parent but they took the time and essentially cared for the whole family with those calls.  
Thank you.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Suzy1966
title: Lost in the system
body:
I was admitted to the SATA ward at the RAH at the beginning of June 2021. It transpired that it was not COVID related and I had an issue with my stomach. I was discharged 2 days later and was advised that a scan would be arranged for me as an out-patient.  
I attended the Victoria Hospital 6 days later for my scan but have never received any results or update. Called my GP who had no record of me having a scan or of who actually arranged it, spoke to medical record at the RAH and they had no idea either.  
Eventually called the SATA ward to be told that a discharge letter had never been completed by the Doctor on the ward and that was the reason there was no follow up. This is now November and I still have no idea of my results or the Consultant who arranged it.  
I just hope that there are not any issues with my scan as 3 months later I am still in the dark. Not very reassuring when I have been completely missed due to a simple admin procedure of doing a letter on my discharge from hospital. Not sure where I go from here??

author: wezenwy77
title: Nobody answers the phone or responds to messages
body:
In May, I suffered a very serious accident and underwent a spinal fusion across 9 vertebrae, along with numerous other procedures. After a lengthy stay in hospital, I was released home and referred for outpatient care at the West Glasgow Ambulatory Care Hospital.  
First follow-up was in July, the consultant was excellent and told me I would be due a further follow-up every 3 months to have further chest xrays and check on the condition of the injury and surrounding vertebrae and the status of the metalwork in my spine, with a view to removing it in 2022.  
I am now past the point that I should have had this appointment, and no letter has been forthcoming, so I have attempted on six separate occasions over the past two weeks to get in touch with the orthopaedic outpatients service, via calling the switchboard. At no time has anyone at orthopaedic outpatients ever answered the phone, and despite multiple messages left detailing my query and giving my name, CHI number and phone number, nobody has been in touch.  
I have some neurological symptoms that I have noticed since my initial follow-up, so I am very keen to find out why no follow-up appointment has materialised, but sadly nobody answers the phone or responds to voicemail.

author: circinustc93
title: Put at ease in clinic
body: I had a talk about Prep and decided to start taking it. I also got tested as I can’t take blood from the home kits myself and so it’s a lot easier to get it done at a clinic. Tracy does a very good job of making me feel at ease as I can go a little faint.

author: jackpotee35
title: Friendly team
body: I was hesitant to attend a clinic due to embarrassment regarding anal warts, but they weren't going away. I shouldn't have been, the team at the clinic were so friendly and put me at ease immediately.

author: Wasso
title: Patient transport service
body: My Father who is in his 90's was kept waiting in the ward sitting in a wheelchair after his dialysis at GRI finished at 5pm and by 6.45 there was still no sign of patient transport to take him home, and this is not a first time. My previous complaints to the Scottish Ambulance Service have ended with me receiving a letter saying they have investigated and it was a one-off.Yesterday my mother was up the wall waiting for him to come home. Firstly I want to thank the two nurses who waited with him till I arrived. Secondly I want to complain about the transport service. The nurses informed me they had been trying to contact the service but no one was picking up the phone. This is what I am complaining mainly about the lack of communication. Knowing why things are not working is half the battle, I know they are only taking one at time due to covid in the ambulance transport and I know COP was on in Glasgow so there have been traffic problems but for the love of god a bit of communication would go a long way. By the way I put no fault at the ambulance transport staff, as far as I can see they just do what they are told but who is running things at the control centre?

readBy.name: Office of John Mason, MSP for Glasgow Shettleston

author: MWG2021
title: Calm and compassionate care
body: I would like to thank Doctor Frew for the amazing treatment given in the emergency care ward. Doctor Frew's professional and calm manner made a very frightening experience manageable. The care and compassion shown for patients is certainly their driving force.

author: chamaeleonkh36

body:
Visit was very good, staff are amazingly helpful. The last time I seen mum she was taken away on an ambulance not looking very well at all. To be able to see mum and speak to her even though she has some dementia was very reassuring. It took mum a little while to realise that I could see her in real time but so worth while, I could also show mum we were looking after her little dog sufficiently.
If you can, try this service 👍

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Angryandfrustrated
title: Long wait in south west acute hospital A&E
body: Wait in a and e for a bed from 8.30pm one evening to 6.30pm three days later. Majority of this time in a side corridor. Let’s see if u publish this on care opinion. I think not. Impartial reporter are interested in the story.
